event.title: was originally set up as a rail town on the Canadian Pacific Railway in 1885

data.event: It was originally set up as a rail town on the Canadian Pacific Railway in 1885.
In 1961, it was finally made accessible by car via Highway 17 of the Trans-Canada Highway.

event.title: 2007, when the Domtar mill shut down

data.event: The forest industry was the largest employer until 2007, when the Domtar mill shut down.

event.title: August 1914, a trapped black bear cub was sold

data.event: In August 1914, a trapped black bear cub was sold to Captain Harry Colebourn in White River, and Colebourn named it Winnipeg, or Winnie, after his hometown of Winnipeg.
Over the years, the animal became the basis for the popular literary character.

event.title: celebrates "Winnie's Hometown Festival" every third week in August

data.event: The town celebrates "Winnie's Hometown Festival" every third week in August.

event.title: 23 January 1935), which is the lowest temperature reported

data.event: Even in Ontario, the coldest recorded temperature was in Iroquois Falls at −58.3 °C (−72.9 °F) (23 January 1935), which is the lowest temperature reported in Eastern Canada too.

event.title: is probably based on the fact that for many years

data.event: White River's reputation for coldest area is probably based on the fact that for many years its reported temperature was deemed "the coldest in the nation today" from the handful of stations reporting daily temperature extremes in newspapers and on radio, climatological stations data being only available monthly to Environment Canada.

event.title: was deemed "the coldest in the nation today

data.event: White River's reputation for coldest area is probably based on the fact that for many years its reported temperature was deemed "the coldest in the nation today" from the handful of stations reporting daily temperature extremes in newspapers and on radio, climatological stations data being only available monthly to Environment Canada.
